fields.heading: STRUCTURE
fields.paragraph:
Its structure is called MVT (or MTV, same thing), which stands for Model-View-Template.

Those are the 3 main components and they work together to connect the user with the database. A loosely interpreted diagram is the following:

fields.heading: MODELS
fields.paragraph: Models are Django's way to communicate with the Database. When we create a model, we make the "skeleton" of a table in PostgreSQL. When we "makemigrations" Django prepares that "skeleton" to be modeled into a complete table, which is then done with the "migrate" command

fields.heading: VIEWS
fields.paragraph:
Views are the part where we introduce logic. We get data from our database with queries, we change/add/delete data and then we decide what the user will see by choosing a template and "passing" context to it. We can see there that the View is the "central hub", as it provides the functionality of the page to do full CRUD (Create-Read-Update-Delete) on our Models (Database), while also displaying the data to the users through Templates.

In the course you will find two different types of Views:

  • Class Based Views (I Think Therefore I Blog)
  • Function Based Views (Boutique Ado)

fields.heading: TEMPLATES
fields.paragraph: Templates are HTML files where we display everything that the user will see. Apart from the usual HTML, we also have Jinja "templating" code. It is usually noticed from the brackets. {{ }} and {% %}. The Templates are the only part of Django that a user sees. The rest are handled by the developers.

fields.heading: REQUESTS
fields.paragraph:
When we talk about requests, we mean HTML requests. While all of them can be used in Django for various applications, the main ones are GET and POST requests.

  • GET requests are used to retrieve data from our database.
  • POST requests are used to add or modify data in our database.
